title: Electric flux - cube in exponential E field

content.question: A cube is located with one of its corners at the origin of an <math alttext="x y z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi><mi>z</mi></math> coordinate system and each face parallel to one of the coordinate planes, as shown in the figure. In this region of space there is an electric field <math alttext="vector E equals, a times i hat, plus open parenthesis, b z times e raised to the negative c z power, close parenthesis, times k hat" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover accent="true"><mi>E</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mover accent="true"><mi>i</mi><mo>^</mo></mover><mo>+</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>z</mi><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>c</mi><mi>z</mi></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>k</mi><mo>^</mo></mover></math>, where <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math>, <math alttext="b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>b</mi></math>, and <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>c</mi></math> are positive constants. Which of the following claims is correct about the magnitude <math alttext="phi sub E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mi>E</mi></msub></math> of the total electric flux passing through the closed surface formed by the cube?

choices.label: A larger value of <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> results in a larger value of <math alttext="phi sub E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mi>E</mi></msub></math>.

A larger value of <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> results in a smaller value of <math alttext="phi sub E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mi>E</mi></msub></math>.

A larger value of <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>c</mi></math> results in a larger value of <math alttext="phi sub E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mi>E</mi></msub></math>.

A larger value of <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>c</mi></math> results in a smaller value of <math alttext="phi sub E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mi>E</mi></msub></math>.

content.answer: A larger value of <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>c</mi></math> results in a smaller value of <math alttext="phi sub E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mi>E</mi></msub></math>.

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
